How comparable are murders to other types of deaths? Comparing the total number of firearm deaths with other types of deaths in this case does not tell us a whole lot with regards to what government policy should be. If people are smoking themselves to death then that is their business, but if people are murdering each other with guns then there is more reason for government intervention. One of the main reasons for government is to stop people from violating the rights of each other so that might does not make right. In a state of nature the strong and the people with the most weapons dominate the weak, but in a civilized society we try to solve disputes in a fair manner. So there is very good reason for the government to get involved when people are using guns to murder, injure, and rob each other.

To try and summarise the arguments against (in order of strength):
 [*]Alcohol and cigarettes tend to kill the user. Guns tend to kill other people. If someone commits suicide, I have much less of an issue than if they kill me instead.[*]There are social (and health-related) benefits to drinking in moderation, whereas there are minimal benefits to owning a gun 'in moderation', sport aside - which I have no issue with. I don't smoke, and have no issue in banning tobacco. I do drink, but would still be quite happy to see a ban on drinks advertising, at minimum - less harsh than smoking because moderate alcohol does negligible damage, as opposed to 'moderate' smoking, which still kills.[*]The purpose of a gun is to kill. While there are secondary purposes, this primary purpose still remains. The purpose of alcohol/smoking is enjoyment - while there are dangerous side effects associated with each, the primary purpose is not a malicious one.[*]Turning the argument on it's head: does this mean that you're only supporting gun ownership because you enjoy owning a gun?

All or nothing logic.

 
 No it's the facts. Life isn't fair, never has been fair, never will be fair. There are people out there that will kill you for looking at them funny. That's just how life works, deal with it.
 
 
A person can be a criminal because they violate only one law but follow all other laws. So a criminal will not necessarily violate a gun law just because he/she has broken another law.

 
 Here's the thing: criminals are already violating the gun laws we have on the books and they'll continue to violate any law you could possibly dream up. I've never seen a single incident of a criminal obeying the laws we have, so to me it suggests evidence of mental retardation to just assume that if a law is passed then maybe somewhere, some criminal will say "Nope, I don't wanna break that law".
 
 
England, for example, has a low gun crime rate which indicates to me that a lot of the criminals must be following gun laws there.

 
 England, however, isn't America.
 
 
I think a lot of other posters have made valid points which you keep dismissing without good reason. You're not getting the whole story by just comparing the total numbers of deaths caused by different things. You have to take more into consideration when determining what government policy should be.

 
 Government policy should be to do what we tell them and not butt in where they aren't required.
iangb

People die from drinking-related car crashes, and lung cancer from second-hand smoke. Partaking in drugs isn't a victimless crime that has no negative consequences, they should stopped being treated so lightly.
As soon as you can prove to me that (proportionally) more people use guns to kill themselves than people are killed by other smokers/drinkers. It's just not as big an issue - and I've already made my view clear on how i would tackle each one.
 
 Shopping at Wal-Mart has a negative chain of consequences, leading back to exploitation of workers and children. People who shop there should suffer the consequences!
 
 
Minimal benefits to owning a gun? So the fact that you can save your family from a psycho, save yourself from the same psycho, and keep criminals from having a corner market on force, are minimal benefits?
Mmhmm, minimal. Compare the number of people 'saved' by a gun with the number of people harmed by one, and then compare all of that with the small fraction of drinkers who are actually harmed by alcohol.
 
 
The design of a gun is the propel a metal projectile at moderate to high velocities.

 Tell me, why did you buy a gun? Was it to propel metal projectiles at high velocities, or was it so you could shoot a criminal if you needed to?
 Compare this with why you buy alcohol.
 
 
I'm supporting gun ownership because it's a right that Americans have, and nothing you do or say it going to change that simple fact.

 So you do believe in the immutable Power of the Constitution? I may be confusing you with SnP...
 
 
The number of people killed by guns is irrelevant, because according to you the number of people killed by any other tool or item is irrelevant.
Not really. More people are killed by guns in the US than by anything else - I'd say that was highly relevant. That some people are smothered by pillows each year is not irrelevant, but it is unavoidable (without banning pillows).
 
 
I own a gun for my own reasons. Since I don't go out and harm anyone, don't try and take my gun away from me.

 "I like to drive at 300mph, but I've never crashed. Since I haven't killed anyone yet, don't try to make driving over the speed limit illegal" [/parody]
 
 
And if you cared about keeping people from being shot, you'd focus more on those that are predisposed to doing the shooting, IE individuals with criminal histories.
I agree that more needs to be done here, but you ignore a large percentage of shooters without criminal records. I'd rather prevent it in the first place than wait to prevent it the second time around.
 
 
At the moment Japan is trying to regulate bleach and amonia because people are killing themselves by inhaling the toxic fumes that result from mixing the two. Their primary purpose might be nothing but cleaning, but that doesn't change the fact that more and more people are choosing this lethal cocktail to end their lives.

 I would say that regulating a potentially lethal anything is a good idea - the more lethal, the more regulations. That's why you don't see 5-year-olds buying chainsaws.
 
 
You're the ones who are babbling about "saving lives", we just want to defend ourselves!

 Have you seen the OP of this thread? Was it by a pro- or anti- gunner?
 Does this mean that it would be a fair criticism that 'the pro-gun side do not care about saving lives'?
 
 
In the UK, not the US.

 Either you can't read, or you can't remember. When I gave the sources, you said exactly the same thing as this, and I pointed out that all four surveys were done in America, by Americans, and were hosted on PubMed - a US site.
 You appear to be grasping at straws.
 
 
Face it: you've omitted the quotes. Omitting quotes doesn't help you much, you know.
Which ones? Were they targeted at me?
 
 Feel free to re-post them, and I'll do my best. Like I said, all I did was respond to the OP and go from there.
iangb
EDIT: Ooops, my internets is slow. Apologies for double-post.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Filter: Real Intention of Anti-gun people
